Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171211edcb0000d


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 8 December 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

There seems to be a consensus that technological innovation is now more critical than ever to maintain the competitiveness of the oil and gas industry. According to Deloitte, “The industry is at a critical juncture where companies must go beyond merely acknowledging the need to innovate and start executing upon this imperative in a systematic way or else their long-term survival may be in jeopardy.” 1

TD 

At the same time, according to the Canadian Oil Sands Innovation Alliance (COSIA), when speaking to Canada’s standing committee on natural resources, “While some technologies are already in or nearing commercialization, many, especially the more transformative ones, could take more than a decade to become available for deployment. There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2

How does the industry pursue innovation to drive real business value realization, find more innovative ways to cut costs, increase revenues, create more productive solutions in exploration and development, and make better decisions on operational risk — all while accelerating the pace to commercial deployment?

For starters, we work together. It sounds like a cliché but when key players, producers, research and technology innovators come together, the opportunity to vastly accelerate common industry agendas is realized. The healthcare industry is a perfect example of such transformative innovation through shared agendas.

Transformative technology like AI, advanced algorithms, machine-learning and cloud systems — powered by the IBM Watson platform — made its first impact in healthcare in 2012 starting with oncology — the study and treatment of cancer and tumors. Why healthcare? Two reasons: First, human health impacts us all, and second, the amount of data in the global healthcare industry is massive and AI systems like IBM Watson are built for big data challenges. Medical journals, clinical studies, medical text books, x-ray and scanning film, and personal healthcare records are full of important data, and the healthcare industry shares a common agenda — to deliver the best possible care to patients.

With this in mind, key healthcare organizations and IBM came together to build an oncology treatment advisor. Watson ingested millions of pieces of structured, unstructured and complex data — from both public and private sources — and dramatically changed the face of patient care. From there, IBM Watson and other industries joined forces to accelerate the pace of advancing common industry challenges within the banking and insurance, manufacturing, retail, education and yes, the oil and gas and mining industries, to drive real innovation across the value chain.

Secondly, when industry players work together on shared agendas, they also align current research, expertise and emergent technology solutions to existing challenges to accelerate immediate term profitability goals.

Notice we’re focusing on immediate term? We all know that when economic climates constrain, the focus rapidly turns to short-term performance as uncertainty drives up risk in longer-term innovation and capital project commitments.

Co-investment in shared industry programs delivers benefits almost impossible to reap as individual organizations, such as reduced project and development resources, reduced costs associated with common deployment environments, lower cost recovery thresholds and the benefit of higher reusability of program components and artifacts that reduces the need for redundant or new work efforts for each project initiation.

Thirdly, when industry players come together to form common agendas, they can more broadly capitalize on technological innovation and research such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and connected operations, predictive analytics, blockchain, cloud and AI. To be an innovator, you need to take risk, and with risk comes increased liability and the possibility of failure. According to the World Economic Forum, “the global oil and gas industry has at least 10 years to go before reaching a similar level of digital maturity to aerospace or automotive.”3

The natural resources industry has access to a tremendous amount of valuable data, technology and research capabilities. They are very good at collecting data, and the growth in data management service providers in the oil and gas industry supports this data collection; However, in the last five to ten years the growth in computing power and advanced technologies to capitalize and draw insight, understanding and predictions from historical data, and public data sources, has not been fully realized. The oil and gas industry still struggles with turning data into actionable insights that drive faster, safer and more intelligent work. The evolution of the industry from outdated legacy systems — not capable of handling the data and computer processing power available today — to more powerful operational focusses enabled digital systems will take time, effort, capital and most of all, a significant cultural change in the way the industry works and operates.

Imperative to the industry is the evolution to a modern operational architecture that can ingest the “4 V’s” of data — volume, variety, velocity and veracity — from internal and external sources, then integrate that insight into enterprise processes and workflows for meaningful outcomes. The advancement of AI platforms focused in specific industry verticals over the last five years, enables computing systems and AI to focus on simplifying the intensive processes and complexity in data collection and information retrieval, and even predictions, allowing the geologists and engineers to make better judgment calls and actions based on their experience and the new insights AI brings to their data sets.

Strategic enablement of digital technologies in the oil and gas industry is now fundamental to its survival. At IBM, we believe there is a place for shared agendas to advance innovation through digital transformation. We’ve just launched the IBM Watson for Natural Resources Innovation program in the Canadian oil and gas industry. This 4-year, thirty million dollar value creation program will advance business transformation and focus on a collaborative approach to reduce time-to-market and drive technology ROI.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13

1Innovation in oil and gas Canada 2016, Monitor Deloitte, Doblin 2016.

2 The future of Canada’s oil and gas sector:  Innovation, sustainable solutions and economic opportunities. Report to standing committee on natural resources.  September 2016, 42nd Parliament, 1st Session.

3 World Economic Forum, January 2017

IBM Canada

IBM lives at the intersection of technology and business. As one of Canada’s top 10 private R&D investors, contributing more than $478 million to Canadian research activities, we are at the forefront of transformative technology and innovation. Our leading cloud-based AI platform is being used by businesses, developers, and universities around the world to fight cancer, improve classroom learning, minimize pollution, enhance agriculture and oil & gas exploration, better manage financial investments and much more.

The Natural Resources Solution Centre in Calgary is dedicated to clients’ in the Canadian oil and gas and mining industries. We are currently embarking on a 4-year thirty-million-dollar innovation program that focusses on performance, productivity and safety in the Canadian oil and gas industry.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13


IN 
i951 : Health Care/Life Sciences

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | nadvtr : Advertorials/Sponsored Content | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171208edc800009


HD Press Gallery
WC 1811 words
PD 7 December 2017
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2017 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: All right. It's time for the long-awaited words of wisdom from the wild and wonderful, the national press gallery. I'll let you decide who's wild and who's wonderful. Stephanie Levitz is with the Canadian Press, you're wonderful; Craig Oliver, the wild man, CTV's political commentator. I do want to bring in some breaking news because a regulatory authority on the Kinder Morgan pipeline has just come out with a ruling that basically lets Kinder Morgan start construction over the objections of the town of Burnaby where it will end up as a terminal for this. It looks, Stephanie, like a green light for Kinder Morgan now. Is the headache over for Justin Trudeau? Or John Horgan might have other plans here.

TD 

STEPHANIE LEVITZ (Canadian Press): Yeah. I mean the issue here of course was that the federal government had approved this, right, in the city of Burnaby just to catch people up. The city of Burnaby was opposing it, and sort of in line with some of the politics right now in British Columbia. And so for the folks to step in and say, look, the federal government, the constitution says the feds own this one, it belongs to them, get going on it, is definitely a significant win for the Liberal government, but it doesn't solve the problem, the broader problem of social license, right, for the pipeline itself. If the city of Burnaby remains opposed, if the province of British Columbia remains opposed, it becomes still a political problem for the governing Liberals no matter what a court might say otherwise.

CRAIG OLIVER (CTV News): There's still an appeal in the federal court of course by six First Nations, and a couple of environmental groups, and the city of Burnaby and Vancouver who are challenging the whole thing on the basis that the Kinder Morgan did not adequately get enough consent from First Nations. And that's what killed one of the northern pipelines, that issue. In this case, though, my friend here is saying the federal government has already approved this and so has the National Energy Board. So the city of Burnaby had been throwing all kinds of roadblocks in the way by refusing permitting, and the Kinder Morgan went to the NEP and said, look, national energy program, and said we need to stop this, we're being tainted by the fact the opposition, the provincial government, and so many others, you have to deal with this because you approved this, and so did Ottawa approve it. And so today that one roadblock is gone, but there's still many others to go, but this was a big one.

MARTIN: Okay. Let's move on because we'll just have to wait and see on that one. I do want to ask you about free trade. I mean we had John Manley on. He sounds a little pessimistic that we're not getting all our eggs in the basket that we need to get into to deal with the fact NAFTA might be going down the toilet. Craig, are we seeing the failure of our ability to negotiate free trades around the world?

OLIVER: Well one has to observe that the incident in Beijing, in which the prime minister, everything seemed to fall apart. The prime minister went into that meeting expecting that he was going to be signing an agreement to launch a free trade negotiation, and it all came apart. The Chinese basically rejected the prime minister wanting to bring his domestic agenda to bear on a free trade deal, his progressive agenda involving women's rights, gender, labour, maybe the whole issue of whether Canada could depend on a decision in the courts there if there is a dispute between partners, all of that. And the Chinese said, no, what they want is strictly a business deal, and that's all they want. In fact they're beginning to sound like the Americans in the sense that they're saying take it or leave it. And the other issue here, which is similar, is that when we're dealing with the Americans, there's an asymmetrical relationship. They are powerful. We're not. And it's the same thing with China. They're saying you want to deal with us, you're going to have to get it our way. So this is the second time the prime minister has left the meeting in tatters, as he did in Vietnam in the case of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. And the Japanese are blaming Trudeau for the fact that that came apart when they were ready to make a deal. So one should worry, I think, about the state of our trade negotiations if everywhere you look three of them now are not going well.

MARTIN: I don't know, do fools rush in on these things.

LEVITZ: Well I was going to play devil's advocate on this a bit, because there's something interesting to be said about what the prime minister talked about in China when he was talking about trade as a driver of populism, right. And he talked about the issue with trade deals being that the ones historically have left people really falling behind, and governments have not done a good enough job putting in place trade deals and then subsequent other agreements, training programs, skills development, that compensate for the industries that end up getting hit negatively by trade deals. And so if the issue here for Mr. Trudeau and the Liberal government is truly to ensure trade agreements that actually benefit everyone, that, you know, bring the benefits of globalization home to everybody, then it's a question of him not being able to land those kind of trade deals. And is that really a bad thing? It's a fair question to ask, right. If NAFTA killed the textiles industry, is it fair to launch another trade deal that's going to kill off another industry?

OLIVER: Yeah. Certainly one of the major drivers of populism in the world, and certainly in the case of Trump and the Republicans, was trade deals they said were bad for them. But who's going to say that we should not have a trade deal with China, especially when we don't know where the Americans are going, and the Chinese right now are feeling that they are now the centre of a new world order. They believe that you're going to have to trade with them whether you like it or not, and this is the way it's got to be. That's the way the Americans are acting also. I don't know how we can say we're not coming back, China, to consider this, and I think I agree with you, the way the prime minister wants to go, many Canadians support it. But do they support it at the loss of a trade and investment deal worth who knows how many jobs and how many billions.

LEVITZ: Part of it, too, is the narrative right. Like you have to wonder that the Trudeau Liberals have not lost control of the narrative on trade deals. To go into China and say we're going to walk out with a trade deal, that's a little aggressive.

OLIVER: And how could they have communicated that so many times and it failed so dismally? What went wrong? Again, the prime minister is not even going to explain what went wrong. MARTIN: I've got to move on. I do want to move on. The Supreme Court Chief Justice Beverley McLachlin made her farewell appearance in the court today. She was presiding over a case of free the beer, not an interesting way to go out. So she leaves the bench after 28 years, and she had some parting words. Let's just hear what she had to say.

BEVERLY MCLACHLIN (Supreme Court Justice): That brings me to thanking the Canadian public who are always behind us. We expect criticism. We often get it. And that's good in a democracy. Our decisions are there and open for comment and criticism. But what I have always felt is that the Canadian public generally supports its justice system and supports this court. And for that I am enormously grateful.

MARTIN: Craig Oliver, great Albertan, might I say. Craig, what do you think is her legacy? Is there one?

OLIVER: I think she has brought more social justice, humanity, she has opened up that court in a way it had never been opened up before to discussion, to some explanation of the kind of decisions they were making. She's just been one of the great chiefs of that court. And she was a woman, first woman in that job. She was an example long before many people thought that women were there, she was there, so she's greatly admired.

MARTIN: Steph, I know you've covered a lot of court cases.

LEVITZ: I have, yeah.

MARTIN: What have you observed about this chief justice?

LEVITZ: Well you know it's interesting you say free the beer is an interesting case to go out on. I actually think it's one, it's a perfectly case for Beverley McLachlin, because in this sense she has opened up the court as Craig said, she's really tried to give access to justice for all Canadians, to give it its due, modernize the court, give more access to journalists, more access to the common citizen. So she's going out on a case that is really about opening the borders of provincial trade, opening the borders of boundaries, and giving Canadians access to beer. It's just sort of fitting, and I do, it's sort of fitting in her legacy. And she's a true trailblazer and Canada's own sort of Ruth Bader Ginsberg you know, and I hope that she continues speaking out publicly once she retires.

MARTIN: Yeah. Well she's going to write a fictional book, apparently she's already got a publisher and the publisher has paid her a lot of dough, so I look forward to seeing that, because I agree with you, every time I've been over there watching her, she just brings an air of dignity to it. She'll be sadly missed. All right, I think she's doing a news conference next week so we'll bring that to you as well. Thank you both. Have a good weekend. We'll talk to you soon.

LEVITZ: Nice to be here.

MARTIN: Coming up, my "Last Word" on someone talking themselves out of cabinet. Please stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)


CO 
knng : Kinder Morgan Inc

IN 
i1 : Energy | i1300006 : Pipeline Transportation | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

NS 
ntra : Transcripts | gdip : International Relations | gpol : Domestic Politics | c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfce : C&E Exclusion Filter | nfcpex : C&E Executive News Filter | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter | niwe : IWE Filter

RE 
cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Bell Media Inc.

AN 
Document ONHILL0020171214edc700007


SE Q&A; Exclusive
HD Energy researcher suggests safety emphasis for gas pipelines facing wary public
BY Ximena Mosqueda-Fernandez
WC 951 words
PD 5 December 2017
SN SNL Daily Gas Report
SC DGR
VOL Issue: 98407
LA English
CY Copyright 2017. SNL Financial LC

LP 

➤ Pipeline opponents' tactics have evolved, representing a broader audience and becoming more sophisticated.

➤ Midstream companies should highlight benefits of pipelines versus trains and natural gas versus coal.

TD 

➤ Getting social license "could be life or death for a certain pipeline."

Michael Webber, author and mechanical engineering professor at the University of Texas at Austin.

Source: University of Texas at Austin

Engineering professor Michael Webber is deputy director of the University of Texas at Austin's Energy Institute, where one of specialties is researching the intersection of energy infrastructure engineering and policy. S&P Global Market Intelligence talked with Webber about the challenges natural gas pipelines face in the current political, regulatory and market environment, as well as potential remedies for the industry. The following is an edited transcript of the conversation.

S&P Global Market Intelligence: There have been some recent decisions stalling or, in some instances, even overturning pipeline project approvals. Is this a sign that courts are becoming more sympathetic to pipeline opponents, or instead are pipeline opponents' arguments becoming more sophisticated?

Michael Webber: I don't think courts have changed their outlooks, necessarily. I do think the opponents have become more sophisticated in two ways. One, I think their coalitions are a little more diverse, so it's not just the environmental groups. They often bring in land-rights groups, and so they get a little more of an ideological spread that way. The other thing is they focus more of their effort on midstream rather than production sites. For a long time, opponents to oil and gas would focus on production to stop the extraction. Then they found over time that stopping the midstream is easier and it has the same effect because if you can't move gas to market, then you wouldn't produce in the first place.

The second piece to this is as time goes on, accidents happen. Every single accident of a pipeline, every spill or leak or problem, becomes part of the collection of evidence against pipelines. Time is on the side of the opponents. The more time goes on, the more accidents will happen, and that's used as part of the case to stop the construction of new pipes.

I think all projects are seeing the same kind of thing, which is more legal action at the midstream level, and more groups are brought to the table for that legal action. Every leak that happens just damns the case. The more leaks that happen, especially if it's the same company or pipeline or region, makes it that much harder to get approval.

Is there anything developers can do to counter this momentum that opponents seem to have?

I'm not sure what the best strategy is, but I think there are advantages if pipeline developers explain the relative safety of pipes versus trains. An alternative to moving by pipe is to move oil by train, for example, and trains have their own safety record that's problematic. They could talk about the comparative safety and cleanliness of the pipe versus the train.

The other thing they could talk about is the comparative safety of piped gas than coal, for example, because there's less pollution from gas and [fewer] people will die from respiratory infection. They've got the argument that pipelines actually offer an environmental advantage, compared to rail or coal. I think you'll start to see that kind of thing happen more and more.

What do midstream companies need to focus on in order to maintain their social license? Is that at risk in a post-Dakota Access and post-Keystone XL U.S.? If it is, how big of a risk factor are we talking about?

I think it is a risk. The midstream sector needs to do a better job developing stakeholder groups they can communicate well with and explain the broader argument of why it's beneficial to have pipelines. It's ultimately something pipeline companies have done a bad job on, that sort of social engagement, and that's how they get opposition. It could be life or death for a certain pipeline, not necessarily to the companies, but if they can't get a social license, they can't get a permit, they can't build or operate the pipeline. Absolutely, it's a high-stakes situation for them.

Looking out to 2018, what's the one area you think pipeline companies should focus on to ensure that a project will be successful?

Pipelines tend to be at their best when they are first built. Brand-new materials degrade over time because the soils shift or because of corrosion of the pipelines. The problem with pipelines is not year one, but maybe year 20, year 40 in its lifetime. One way to deal with that is to build in a fund that accumulates money so when the money is needed to improve or replace a pipeline, the money is available. It's easier to do that early on before you need it than to wait until you need it to do it. I feel like that should be part of what's going on with pipelines is built-in funding for when inevitably a problem occurs, to avoid that problem and then to mitigate that problem.

Is there anything else you want to mention that we have not covered?

The infrastructure of midstream, in general, is an important part of energy, not just for oil and gas and pipelines. Moving energy around is a difficult task and is required for all forms of energy.


CO 
unvtxa : University of Texas at Austin

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
usa : United States | austin : Austin | namz : North America | uss : Southern U.S. | ustx : Texas

IPD 
Gas Transportation

PUB 
SNL Financial LC

AN 
Document DGR0000020171206edc500005


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 1 December 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

There seems to be a consensus that technological innovation is now more critical than ever to maintain the competitiveness of the oil and gas industry. According to Deloitte, “The industry is at a critical juncture where companies must go beyond merely acknowledging the need to innovate and start executing upon this imperative in a systematic way or else their long-term survival may be in jeopardy.”1

TD 

At the same time, according to the Canadian Oil Sands Innovation Alliance (COSIA), when speaking to Canada’s standing committee on natural resources, “While some technologies are already in or nearing commercialization, many, especially the more transformative ones, could take more than a decade to become available for deployment. There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2

How does the industry pursue innovation to drive real business value realization, find more innovative ways to cut costs, increase revenues, create more productive solutions in exploration and development, and make better decisions on operational risk — all while accelerating the pace to commercial deployment?

For starters, we work together. It sounds like a cliché but when key players, producers, research and technology innovators come together, the opportunity to vastly accelerate common industry agendas is realized. The healthcare industry is a perfect example of such transformative innovation through shared agendas.

Transformative technology like AI, advanced algorithms, machine-learning and cloud systems — powered by the IBM Watson platform — made its first impact in healthcare in 2012 starting with oncology — the study and treatment of cancer and tumors. Why healthcare? Two reasons: First, human health impacts us all, and second, the amount of data in the global healthcare industry is massive and AI systems like IBM Watson are built for big data challenges. Medical journals, clinical studies, medical text books, x-ray and scanning film, and personal healthcare records are full of important data, and the healthcare industry shares a common agenda — to deliver the best possible care to patients.

With this in mind, key healthcare organizations and IBM came together to build an oncology treatment advisor. Watson ingested millions of pieces of structured, unstructured and complex data — from both public and private sources — and dramatically changed the face of patient care. From there, IBM Watson and other industries joined forces to accelerate the pace of advancing common industry challenges within the banking and insurance, manufacturing, retail, education and yes, the oil and gas and mining industries, to drive real innovation across the value chain.

Secondly, when industry players work together on shared agendas, they also align current research, expertise and emergent technology solutions to existing challenges to accelerate immediate term profitability goals.

Notice we’re focusing on immediate term? We all know that when economic climates constrain, the focus rapidly turns to short-term performance as uncertainty drives up risk in longer-term innovation and capital project commitments.

Co-investment in shared industry programs delivers benefits almost impossible to reap as individual organizations, such as reduced project and development resources, reduced costs associated with common deployment environments, lower cost recovery thresholds and the benefit of higher reusability of program components and artifacts that reduces the need for redundant or new work efforts for each project initiation.

Thirdly, when industry players come together to form common agendas, they can more broadly capitalize on technological innovation and research such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and connected operations, predictive analytics, blockchain, cloud and AI. To be an innovator, you need to take risk, and with risk comes increased liability and the possibility of failure. According to the World Economic Forum, “the global oil and gas industry has at least 10 years to go before reaching a similar level of digital maturity to aerospace or automotive.”3

The natural resources industry has access to a tremendous amount of valuable data, technology and research capabilities. They are very good at collecting data, and the growth in data management service providers in the oil and gas industry supports this data collection; However, in the last five to ten years the growth in computing power and advanced technologies to capitalize and draw insight, understanding and predictions from historical data, and public data sources, has not been fully realized. The oil and gas industry still struggles with turning data into actionable insights that drive faster, safer and more intelligent work. The evolution of the industry from outdated legacy systems — not capable of handling the data and computer processing power available today — to more powerful operational focusses enabled digital systems will take time, effort, capital and most of all, a significant cultural change in the way the industry works and operates.

Imperative to the industry is the evolution to a modern operational architecture that can ingest the “4 V’s” of data — volume, variety, velocity and veracity — from internal and external sources, then integrate that insight into enterprise processes and workflows for meaningful outcomes. The advancement of AI platforms focused in specific industry verticals over the last five years, enables computing systems and AI to focus on simplifying the intensive processes and complexity in data collection and information retrieval, and even predictions, allowing the geologists and engineers to make better judgment calls and actions based on their experience and the new insights AI brings to their data sets.

Strategic enablement of digital technologies in the oil and gas industry is now fundamental to its survival. At IBM, we believe there is a place for shared agendas to advance innovation through digital transformation. We’ve just launched the IBM Watson for Natural Resources Innovation program in the Canadian oil and gas industry. This 4-year, thirty million dollar value creation program will advance business transformation and focus on a collaborative approach to reduce time-to-market and drive technology ROI.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13    

1Innovation in oil and gas Canada 2016, Monitor Deloitte, Doblin 2016.

2 The future of Canada’s oil and gas sector:  Innovation, sustainable solutions and economic opportunities. Report to standing committee on natural resources.  September 2016, 42nd Parliament, 1st Session.

3 World Economic Forum, January 2017

IBM Canada

IBM lives at the intersection of technology and business. As one of Canada’s top 10 private R&D investors, contributing more than $478 million to Canadian research activities, we are at the forefront of transformative technology and innovation. Our leading cloud-based AI platform is being used by businesses, developers, and universities around the world to fight cancer, improve classroom learning, minimize pollution, enhance agriculture and oil & gas exploration, better manage financial investments and much more.

The Natural Resources Solution Centre in Calgary is dedicated to clients’ in the Canadian oil and gas and mining industries. We are currently embarking on a 4-year thirty-million-dollar innovation program that focusses on performance, productivity and safety in the Canadian oil and gas industry.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13   


IN 
i951 : Health Care/Life Sciences

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | nadvtr : Advertorials/Sponsored Content | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171201edc10000c


HD Questerre Consolidates Antler Working Interest
WC 319 words
PD 27 November 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Questerre Energy Corporation says that it has closed an acquisition of producing Bakken/Torquay oil assets in the Antler area of southeast Saskatchewan.

The accretive acquisition consolidates the company’s operated working interest at Antler, Michael Binnion, president and chief executive officer of Questerre, said in a news release. “We now own 100 per cent of these assets and add low-decline, high netback light oil production to our base of conventional assets.”

TD 

Post the acquisition, current production from the area, including adjacent production from Pierson, Man., is approximately 450 bbl/d, he said.

Questerre acquired approximately 180 bbls/d of light oil production in the Antler area for gross consideration of $7.25 million, subject to customary industry adjustments. Acquired assets include 3D seismic data over the producing acreage with a value of approximately $770,000.

The effective date of the acquisition is Oct. 1, 2017. The company’s independent reserve engineers will evaluate the proved and probable reserves associated with the assets in conjunction with the year-end 2017 reserve evaluation.

Questerre also reported that it is submitting its comments on the draft hydrocarbon regulations to the ministry of Energy and Natural Resources in Quebec this week. The company said it anticipates that subject to the review of the comments received from stakeholders, the regulations should be finalized in early 2018.

Questerre said it is leveraging its expertise gained through early exposure to shale and other non-conventional reservoirs. It has base production and reserves in the tight oil Bakken/Torquay of southeast Saskatchewan and is bringing on production from its lands in the heart of the high-liquids Montney shale fairway.

The company said it is a leader on social license to operate issues for its Utica shale gas discovery in the St. Lawrence Lowlands, Que., and is pursuing oil shale projects with the aim of commercially developing these massive resources.

 


CO 
questc : Questerre Energy Corp

IN 
i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | iextra : Natural Gas/Oil Extraction

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cask : Saskatchewan | cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171127edbr0000a


SE Canadian Politics
HD The slippery politics of pipelines: Canada's biggest projects and the political lives that depend on them
BY Stuart Thomson
WC 1046 words
PD 27 November 2017
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

The politics of pipelines used to be a lot simpler.

It used to be Conservative Prime Minister Stephen Harper thundering to U.S. lawmakers( http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/harper-won-t-take-no-for-an-answer-on-keystone-xl-1.1869439[http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/harper-won-t-take-no-for-an-answer-on-keystone-xl-1.1869439] ) that he won't take no for an answer on the Keystone XL pipeline. At the time, environmentalists and left-leaning politicians were appropriately aghast.

TD 

Now, an NDP Alberta premier is touring the country - or at least a few select cities - touting the benefits of pipelines that take Albertan oil to market.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has borrowed Rachel Notley's logic, framing his environmental policies as a way to smooth over pipeline approvals and win "social license" for the emissions-intense bitumen shipped from the oil sands.

As Canadians start to feel the pinch from newly-introduced carbon taxes, the pipelines - and the jobs they bring - take on an increased importance.

Here's where the major pipeline projects stand as we push into the second half of both Notley and Trudeau's first term in power.

Keystone XL

If you didn't see any touchdown celebrations after Nebraska approved the $8 billion Keystone XL pipeline this week, that's because it came with some major caveats.

It may also be because everyone involved in the Keystone pipeline is pretty jaded after former U.S. President Barack Obama delayed the project in 2011, before finally killing it in 2015. It was revitalized this year by Donald Trump, but there's still major hurdles to clear.

The approval from Nebraska requires a new route, which will cause all kinds of construction and legal complications in that state and possibly a whole new review( https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21731670-no-guarantee-it-will-actually-be-built-keystone-xl-pipeline-has-won-approval[https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21731670-no-guarantee-it-will-actually-be-built-keystone-xl-pipeline-has-won-approval] ) in neighbouring South Dakota.

And in any event, some people doubt the economic viability of the pipeline( https://www.forbes.com/sites/arthurberman/2017/02/03/the-keystone-xl-pipeline-a-risky-bet-on-higher-oil-prices-and-tight-oil/#535698657f88[https://www.forbes.com/sites/arthurberman/2017/02/03/the-keystone-xl-pipeline-a-risky-bet-on-higher-oil-prices-and-tight-oil/#535698657f88] ), which needs oil prices to be fairly high to make a profit.

That's why most Canadian politicians have been looking elsewhere( http://calgaryherald.com/news/politics/ndp-energy-minister-wants-to-help-get-energy-east-pipeline-built[http://calgaryherald.com/news/politics/ndp-energy-minister-wants-to-help-get-energy-east-pipeline-built] ) for a pipeline to hang their political hats on.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks with pipeline protestors as they stand and hold signs at a town hall at the University of Winnipeg in Winnipeg, Thursday, January 26, 2017.

Trans Mountain

The Trans Mountain pipeline is one of the few bright lights on the pipeline front. Not only has it cleared regulatory hurdles, but it also takes Alberta oil to the west coast, which will get a better price.

Kinder Morgan has already started site preparations and terminal construction and expects to begin pipeline construction in February.

That's not to say its supporters aren't worried. It's still waiting on a judicial review and Notley spent this week campaigning across Canada( https://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwjYw6CTytfXAhUr7YMKHU5vDOgQqUMIKjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fnationalpost.com%2Fopinion%2Fkelly-mcparland-notley-makes-an-unlikely-champion-for-pipelines-but-shes-sure-trying&usg=AOvVaw0z9pRHtgkEefDZADflSYyF[https://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwjYw6CTytfXAhUr7YMKHU5vDOgQqUMIKjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fnationalpost.com%2Fopinion%2Fkelly-mcparland-notley-makes-an-unlikely-champion-for-pipelines-but-shes-sure-trying&usg=AOvVaw0z9pRHtgkEefDZADflSYyF] ) in support of the pipeline. Proponents look at the Dakota Access Pipeline protests in the United States and wonder if something similar could happen in Canada.

As Edmonton Journal columnist Graham Thomson wrote on Thursday, "Notley needs construction of the project to begin in 2018 to have a fighting chance in the 2019 provincial election."

Trudeau's problem isn't existential like Notley's, but not getting Trans Mountain built, after vetoing the Northern Gateway pipeline and seeing TransCanada kill Energy East will still come with a political price.

Line 3 Replacement

Amid the frenzied celebrations from politicians( http://edmontonjournal.com/opinion/columnists/graham-thomson-ndp-gloat-over-pipeline-approvals-as-rachel-notley-plans-trip-to-b-c[http://edmontonjournal.com/opinion/columnists/graham-thomson-ndp-gloat-over-pipeline-approvals-as-rachel-notley-plans-trip-to-b-c] ) in Alberta for the Trans Mountain approval, Enbridge's Line 3 expansion pipeline got a little shortchanged on fanfare.

Although Trans Mountain is more likely to get name-checked, the Alberta NDP constantly references the "two pipeline approvals" won on their watch, with the second one being Line 3.

The pipeline was approved last year - at the same time as Trans Mountain - and is a $8.2 billion project, with $5.3 billion worth of it happening in Canada. The pipeline runs from Hardisty, AB to Wisconsin.

The plan is to replace the existing Line 3 with a new pipeline, improving safety and boosting capacity, which perhaps explains why it flew under the radar.

Despite that, Enbridge is still bickering with Minnesota about final approval of the deal. A ruling in December( http://www.ctvnews.ca/business/enbridge-says-line-3-project-progressing-despite-rising-scrutiny-in-minnesota-1.3660206[http://www.ctvnews.ca/business/enbridge-says-line-3-project-progressing-despite-rising-scrutiny-in-minnesota-1.3660206] ) from that state will decide if the project goes ahead as planned.

Energy East and Northern Gateway

These two pipelines are dead, although recriminations over why are still flying.

Northern Gateway ran into trouble, in part, because the courts believed the government hadn't adequately consulted with First Nations about the project. Alongside the decision to approve Line 3 and Trans Mountain, Trudeau also pulled the plug on Northern Gateway, saying it didn't serve the best interests of the affected communities.

Energy East was killed by TransCanada itself, and some blamed the burdensome regulatory environment for the company's decision. Others blamed the economics of the pipeline( http://business.financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-economic-reality-killed-the-energy-east-pipe-dream-and-thats-good[http://business.financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-economic-reality-killed-the-energy-east-pipe-dream-and-thats-good] ), which required oil to be at a price that may not be realistic anymore.

That is a common thread running through all the new pipeline projects in Canada. With oil prices stagnating, competing shale oil showing no signs of slowing down and carbon pricing soon to be a reality across the country, the cost benefit analysis of every pipeline is changing for the worse.

. Email: sxthomson@postmedia.com( mailto:sxthomson@postmedia.com ) Twitter: stuartxthomson( http://twitter.com/stuartxthomson[http://twitter.com/stuartxthomson] )


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | genv : Natural Environment | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

IPD 
politics,pipelines,simpler,conservative,prime,minister

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020171127edbr00461


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 24 November 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

There seems to be a consensus that technological innovation is now more critical than ever to maintain the competitiveness of the oil and gas industry. According to Deloitte, “The industry is at a critical juncture where companies must go beyond merely acknowledging the need to innovate and start executing upon this imperative in a systematic way or else their long-term survival may be in jeopardy.” 1

TD 

At the same time, according to the Canadian Oil Sands Innovation Alliance (COSIA), when speaking to Canada’s standing committee on natural resources, “While some technologies are already in or nearing commercialization, many, especially the more transformative ones, could take more than a decade to become available for deployment. There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2

How does the industry pursue innovation to drive real business value realization, find more innovative ways to cut costs, increase revenues, create more productive solutions in exploration and development, and make better decisions on operational risk — all while accelerating the pace to commercial deployment?

For starters, we work together. It sounds like a cliché but when key players, producers, research and technology innovators come together, the opportunity to vastly accelerate common industry agendas is realized. The healthcare industry is a perfect example of such transformative innovation through shared agendas.

Transformative technology like AI, advanced algorithms, machine-learning and cloud systems — powered by the IBM Watson platform — made its first impact in healthcare in 2012 starting with oncology — the study and treatment of cancer and tumors. Why healthcare? Two reasons: First, human health impacts us all, and second, the amount of data in the global healthcare industry is massive and AI systems like IBM Watson are built for big data challenges. Medical journals, clinical studies, medical text books, x-ray and scanning film, and personal healthcare records are full of important data, and the healthcare industry shares a common agenda — to deliver the best possible care to patients.

With this in mind, key healthcare organizations and IBM came together to build an oncology treatment advisor. Watson ingested millions of pieces of structured, unstructured and complex data — from both public and private sources — and dramatically changed the face of patient care. From there, IBM Watson and other industries joined forces to accelerate the pace of advancing common industry challenges within the banking and insurance, manufacturing, retail, education and yes, the oil and gas and mining industries, to drive real innovation across the value chain.

Secondly, when industry players work together on shared agendas, they also align current research, expertise and emergent technology solutions to existing challenges to accelerate immediate term profitability goals.

Notice we’re focusing on immediate term? We all know that when economic climates constrain, the focus rapidly turns to short-term performance as uncertainty drives up risk in longer-term innovation and capital project commitments.

Co-investment in shared industry programs delivers benefits almost impossible to reap as individual organizations, such as reduced project and development resources, reduced costs associated with common deployment environments, lower cost recovery thresholds and the benefit of higher reusability of program components and artifacts that reduces the need for redundant or new work efforts for each project initiation.

Thirdly, when industry players come together to form common agendas, they can more broadly capitalize on technological innovation and research such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and connected operations, predictive analytics, blockchain, cloud and AI. To be an innovator, you need to take risk, and with risk comes increased liability and the possibility of failure. According to the World Economic Forum, “the global oil and gas industry has at least 10 years to go before reaching a similar level of digital maturity to aerospace or automotive.”3

The natural resources industry has access to a tremendous amount of valuable data, technology and research capabilities. They are very good at collecting data, and the growth in data management service providers in the oil and gas industry supports this data collection; However, in the last five to ten years the growth in computing power and advanced technologies to capitalize and draw insight, understanding and predictions from historical data, and public data sources, has not been fully realized. The oil and gas industry still struggles with turning data into actionable insights that drive faster, safer and more intelligent work. The evolution of the industry from outdated legacy systems — not capable of handling the data and computer processing power available today — to more powerful operational focusses enabled digital systems will take time, effort, capital and most of all, a significant cultural change in the way the industry works and operates.

Imperative to the industry is the evolution to a modern operational architecture that can ingest the “4 V’s” of data — volume, variety, velocity and veracity — from internal and external sources, then integrate that insight into enterprise processes and workflows for meaningful outcomes. The advancement of AI platforms focused in specific industry verticals over the last five years, enables computing systems and AI to focus on simplifying the intensive processes and complexity in data collection and information retrieval, and even predictions, allowing the geologists and engineers to make better judgment calls and actions based on their experience and the new insights AI brings to their data sets.

Strategic enablement of digital technologies in the oil and gas industry is now fundamental to its survival. At IBM, we believe there is a place for shared agendas to advance innovation through digital transformation. We’ve just launched the IBM Watson for Natural Resources Innovation program in the Canadian oil and gas industry. This 4-year, thirty million dollar value creation program will advance business transformation and focus on a collaborative approach to reduce time-to-market and drive technology ROI.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13

1Innovation in oil and gas Canada 2016, Monitor Deloitte, Doblin 2016.

2 The future of Canada’s oil and gas sector:  Innovation, sustainable solutions and economic opportunities. Report to standing committee on natural resources.  September 2016, 42nd Parliament, 1st Session.

3 World Economic Forum, January 2017

IBM Canada

IBM lives at the intersection of technology and business. As one of Canada’s top 10 private R&D investors, contributing more than $478 million to Canadian research activities, we are at the forefront of transformative technology and innovation. Our leading cloud-based AI platform is being used by businesses, developers, and universities around the world to fight cancer, improve classroom learning, minimize pollution, enhance agriculture and oil & gas exploration, better manage financial investments and much more.

The Natural Resources Solution Centre in Calgary is dedicated to clients’ in the Canadian oil and gas and mining industries. We are currently embarking on a 4-year thirty-million-dollar innovation program that focusses on performance, productivity and safety in the Canadian oil and gas industry.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13


IN 
i951 : Health Care/Life Sciences

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | nadvtr : Advertorials/Sponsored Content | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171124edbo00009


HD View From The Hill
WC 2803 words
PD 21 November 2017
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2017 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: Welcome back. Our Tuesday trio of MPs representing three major parties are here to dig into the auditor general's findings from other, different viewpoints, I suspect. Michelle Rempel is a Conservative MP from Calgary, and Nathan Cullen, an NDP MP from northern British Columbia. And for the defence, Liberal parliamentary secretary, Steve Mackinnon, who was handling like, you were handling all that Phoenix debacle today. That wasn't any fun for you at all, but, I think it's more interesting, you can't get through to pay your taxes.

TD 

NATHAN CULLEN (NDP - British Columbia): What?

MARTIN: This is going with that tax narrative. These guys have the inability to deal with anything taxation-wise. What the heck, Steven Mackinnon? How come, how can they not get through to find out how much taxes I owe your government?

STEVEN MACKINNON (Public Services Parliamentary Secretary): Well, obviously it's not acceptable that citizens don't get this most elementary level of service and that's something that we're going to have to fix. And we've put in place an awful lot of things that will, in fact, fix it. We've invested, yes, in catching tax evasion, tax avoidance. We've invested in training. We're investing in technological solutions. You know, we have a 20-year-old phone system in that department. We have insufficient training. We have insufficient resources and there is a common thread that weaves through all of the elements of the auditor general's report today, and it's important to say that that was important work, and we accept, and accepted all his recommendations.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

CULLEN: ...that was important.

MACKINNON: What, what you, what you see is this under investment in the most basic infrastructure, the plumbing, if you will...

MARTIN: Right.

MACKINNON: ...of the government of Canada.

MARTIN: Yeah. You've had two years.

MACKINNON: Over the last ten years, in fact, we have had two years, and our, I think our track record's very good of reinvesting in the system, but we have inherited bad IT systems, a very bad infrastructure in the federal government.

CULLEN: Stephen Harper made us do it.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MARTIN: Okay...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MARTIN: ...inheritance.

MACKINNON: We have to get back to these basics...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MACKINNON: ...as the auditor general says, the basics of service to citizens.

MARTIN: Michelle, it's always your government's fault. How do you plead?

(LAUGHTER)

MICHELLE REMPEL (Conservative Immigration Critic): Look, to me, this at this point, is really about getting public servants paid. Prior to entering politics, I was involved in a much smaller scale legacy system renewal, in my previous job with a big institution, and it was hard. I mean, this is about selecting the right software and then making sure that you've got a plan in place to execute it. You know, our leader today mentioned...

MACKINNON: Would have been nice to see that in Phoenix.

REMPEL: Hey, let me finish.

MARTIN: Let her finish.

REMPEL: Okay, well, since, since you're pushing me on this, the, you know, my leader today mentioned the fact that the Liberals actually had two reports presented to them saying don't press start. This is going to cause major problems. And they ignored that. You know, certainly when we were in government, Tony Clement today was saying, look, we got the same information. It wasn't ready. So, you know, I think the Liberals do have to take some responsibility for that decision, but then more importantly, what we need to measure now is how quickly the Liberals are fixing this problem because it's, it's not, it's, you know, they're talking about whole-of-government approach. It's a whole-of-government mess, like everybody's not being paid. And, you know, I don't think that's a positive thing.

MARTIN: I was going to get to Phoenix later, but I was talking about the CRA.

REMPEL: Oh, sure, sorry. Sorry.

MARTIN: And your leader actually made a very interesting point. He says, you know, if my name was Stephen Bronfman, I would have got the prime minister to immediately give a ruling on taxes. Instead, I can't even get through to the CRA. What did you make of that?

CULLEN: Okay, so the numbers are pretty impressive...

(LAUGHTER)

CULLEN: ...if you want to use that term. Half of all calls going into the revenue agency are not picked up at all.

MARTIN: Yeah.

MARTIN: Just ignored.

MARTIN: Yeah.

REMPEL: Yeah.

MARTIN: Of, of those that make it through, one-third are getting bad, or wrong advice on their taxes. Here's what you should file. Here's how you should file. And a third of the time...

MARTIN: Oops.

CULLEN: ...it's wrong.

MARTIN: Yeah.

CULLEN: So, sure this is plumbing. That's one term for it. It brings up other ideas and images, but it's...

MARTIN: I knew where you were going there.

CULLEN: ...it's a basic, basic function of government. And you extend that over to the Phoenix, which is just paying people for the work they did, and Michelle's right, when the Conservatives came up with this idea, took Phoenix off the shelf and said will this work? They had reports in front of them that said it will not. The Liberals had the same reports, and they said we're going ahead anyway...

MACKINNON: Not quite how it went down.

CULLEN: No, no. I was there.

MACKINNON: Well, and so was I.

CULLEN: I was there. No. No you weren't actually.

MARTIN: Yeah, you were a rookie. You were a rookie.

CULLEN: So, the Liberals ignored the advice and said no, we're going to start it anyways. The problem is this, for Canadians, is this is all costing people enormous amounts of stress. I have people in my riding losing their houses. We've had marriages been breaking up because they don't get paid for months. Students that worked for the federal government last summer, also not paid for months. So, they knew the problem was there. They ignored it. They went ahead. And we say, well, when is it going to be fixed? And the auditor general says we don't know.

MARTIN: Maybe never.

CULLEN: Maybe never...

(LAUGHTER)

MACKINNON: ...in and out of this, fundamentally, this government's eye has not come off the Phoenix ball from day one.

MARTIN: Well, it was supposed to be fixed last October...

MACKINNON: And, and...

CULLEN: That's right.

MACKINNON: ...and there is documented evidence of that. We've added...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MACKINNON: ...we've added resources at every stop. We've added technology improvements.

(LAUGHTER)

MACKINNON: We've added all sorts of things to it and, and it's easy to be glib about this, but...

MARTIN: He's not being glib...

MACKINNON: But Nathan and Michelle should be careful about what they ask for because the auditor general's coming out with another report...

CULLEN: Oh!

MACKINNON: ...on the origins of this system, and I'm afraid it's going to be very damning, a damning one. The, the, but on the point, and this is an important point, Don. You've got to let me get this in.

MARTIN: Okay. Then she's...

MACKINNON: You've got to let me get this in. The choice facing the government was not Phoenix or the old system. The old system was gone. It had been retired. The people were fired by Mr. Harper.

MARTIN: I know. I can see that.

MACKINNON: The choice was Phoenix or no pay system.

MARTIN: Right.

MACKINNON: So the choice about turning on the Phoenix pay system and making it...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MARTIN: Go ahead, Michelle.

REMPEL: Okay. Thank you. I guess two points. I want to make a point on these comments as well as the CRA issue. First of all, I'm putting myself in the shoes right now of somebody who hasn't gotten paid, who's watching this at home, and watching this happen, going just fix it.

CULLEN: That's right.

REMPEL: Like nothing that's been said today is, how is this going to get fixed? How am I going to know that, that paycheque is coming? And really, what we need to hold the government to account to, and where the government needs to quickly go is saying this is how we're fixing it, rather than, you know, trying to diffuse blame, because we have to go forward. On the CRA thing, I just want to echo what Nathan said. You know, a lot of times the case work that we get in any of our offices are, are people who are having difficulties with CRA because they've gotten wrong information. And if the government is giving wrong information, I, they're, you know, I don't know what sort of liability is there...

CULLEN: Well, there's not because we have cases for people who got the wrong advice from CRA of how to file.

MARTIN: And?

CULLEN: They lose, they lost their business...

REMPEL: Yeah.

CULLEN: And CRA is not culpable for the advice that they gave over the phone.

REMPEL: Yeah.

CULLEN: That's, that's a...

REMPEL: It's a problem.

CULLEN: ...that's a fact and it's a huge problem for a government to pull back and say, it's, if I hear the Liberals say this is unacceptable one more time, I'm going to have to look up what unacceptable means, because it clearly is acceptable.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

CULLEN: A year ago, you said you were going to fix Phoenix and you didn't. That's the fact.

MACKINNON: ...to be glib about this.

MARTIN: No.

MACKINNON: It's a heavy lift.

CULLEN: How's that glib?

MACKINNON: There's a lot of very hard work to do and a lot was...

CULLEN: And half a billion...

MACKINNON: ...was messed up, and a lot of had to be fixed. I represent, I will add for my friend, probably the biggest proportion of public servants in the country.

MARTIN: Right.

CULLEN: They must be (inaudible) with you.

MACKINNON: ...in my riding, and they understand...

MARTIN: Right.

MACKINNON: ...there is not a millimetre of light between us, the public sector unions or their motivation to fix this problem. We are going to fix this problem. We are going to apply the resources required to fix this problem. I hear, I hear, I understand...

REMPEL: Look, what, what do you need to know now?

MACKINNON: I understand the Conservatives and the NDP just screaming just fix it. At the end of the day, that's what we're doing.

REMPEL: But we're two years in. Why aren't we measuring you on what, like, you should be saying what you're going to do to fix it, so we can have that conversation, but you're not saying that here today.

MACKINNON: We actually have published a sixteen-point plan on the...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MARTIN: We're going into a bit of a circle. I want to get Michelle expertise on this, because you're the immigration critic.

REMPEL: Yes.

MARTIN: What did you make of the refugee settlement thing? It sounds to me like the auditor general is saying the services, the money wasn't there to provide the services in the right location when they were needed for these Syrian refugees. What was your read?

REMPEL: That's exactly right. Essentially, the report said what we've been saying all along, is that the emphasis was placed so much on, you know, the arrivals of the refugee rather than the hard work of providing integration services on the back end. The report confirms that we found in a parliamentary study that showed people were not getting access, timely access to language training services. The government isn't measuring basic things like whether or not children are able to attend school. So the, the report really exposed a flaw in the government's ability to provide integration support for refugees. And this is so off brand for the government, right? So for me, you know, I hope that this is, the report is a wake-up call for the government that, you know, these, these photo-op policies aren't good enough in terms of instilling confidence in the public to support social license for immigration, and that these are people. They're not numbers. And we have to be providing these services to them so that they have a successful experience here in Canada. It was a disappointing report.

MARTIN: Nathan?

CULLEN: As complicated and hard as it is to get a large number of refugees out of war-torn areas, and get them to Canada, the actual even larger work is making sure they're successful when they get here. The government spent a great deal of time and energy and there was some photo-op aspect to this of welcoming this many refugees to town, to Canada without the plan in place to support them. That's what the auditor general told us. I think Michelle's point is well taken that if we want broad support for refugees to be able to come to Canada, immigration in general, Canadians need to see the program as successful for those people and those families as they come into Canada, rather than unsuccessful, which we've seen in Europe and other places. So, more than a wake-up call, this is a, a serious thing, longer-term beyond even just these families who are impacted.

MARTIN: Yeah, we've got to get them integrated successfully, or else this is going to be non-stop...

MACKINNON: Yeah. But, you know, there are so many great stories out there, and what they call photo-op, very cynically, is actually an example to the world. And we have mobilized, the federal government has...

CULLEN: Did you read the auditor's report?

MACKINNON: ...enormous resources, enormous resources to welcome this number of refugees to Canada. Things have gone very well. Things have happened very quickly. And the entire government was involved. Canadians should be very proud of how we are leading the way.

CULLEN: Did we read the same auditor general's report?

REMPEL: I, I don't think so.

CULLEN: I don't, I'm confused by this.

REMPEL: I was, I was expecting, we accept there were findings...

CULLEN: Exactly.

REMPEL: ...of the report, and we're going to move on it, line. No, the report very clearly said that things aren't going well. And my concern is for, you know, I've been a passionate advocate for...

MACKINNON: Well, again...

REMPEL: ...refugees...

MACKINNON: Look.

REMPEL: ...that came in as victims of the Yazidi genocide.

MACKINNON: Yes, and you brought in three.

REMPEL: And we need to make sure that we...

MACKINNON: You brought in three.

REMPEL: Well, actually we brought in a lot more than that recently. We should have more.

MACKINNON: Since, since you were there, we have, yes...

REMPEL: ...but the reality is, it's like we're hearing things like people don't have access to interpretation services. They don't have access to healthcare. I had an official tell me in committee that only five of these women have been able to access one-on-one counselling support. So, it's like, the back end is what we need, right?

CULLEN: I'm still confused by this response...

MARTIN: Very quickly. I'm out of time.

CULLEN: I want them to be successful on this. Canadians wanted them to be successful.

MARTIN: Oh, yeah.

CULLEN: One of the things...

MACKINNON: Well, and then, then you call it photo-ops. I mean.

CULLEN: Hold on. Allow me. Allow me...

MACKINNON: That's just bizarre.

CULLEN: In order to be successful, you actually have to do the hard work of integrating refugees into Canada.

REMPEL: Yeah.

CULLEN: The auditor general...

MACKINNON: I'll invite you onto the ground...

CULLEN: Oh, my gosh.

MARTIN: Okay, onto the green room...

CULLEN: The auditor general gave you a failure on this.

MARTIN: This conversation...

CULLEN: It's good to pay attention to it.

MARTIN: We've got to wind it up.

CULLEN: Respect it.

MACKINNON: We're paying deep attention to it.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: Nicely done. Okay. There's a green room over there. You can keep talking. We'll see you later.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: Thanks for coming, all of you. Coming up, pursuing a pipeline dream, the Alberta premier is standing by. Please stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)


NS

SE News
HD Thanks, Trump!
BY Lorne Gunter
CR Edmonton Sun
WC 648 words
PD 21 November 2017
SN The Edmonton Sun
SC EDMNTN
ED Final
PG A5
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 The Edmonton Sun

LP 

Donald Trump may have saved Rachel Notley's political hide.

Admittedly, an NDP win remains a real long shot in the 2019 election.

TD 

But for the NDP to have any shot, at least one major pipeline has to be under construction by the time the election is called in the spring of 2019.

A lot else has to be going right, too.

The price of oil has to continue its climb from where it is now (in the $55US range) to around $70US. The NDP have to reduce spending and begin to get their deficit under control. And tens of thousands of energy-sector workers have to be back working again.

Still, if the Alberta economy is humming when the election is called two years from now, there is an extremely narrow path to victory for the New Democrats.

Since Keystone XL (KXL) is the pipeline most likely to be under construction by 2019, Notley and the NPD owe their tiny sliver of hope to the U.S. president.

After all, it was Trump who agreed to give federal permits to the $8-billion pipeline project back in March. That reversed seven years of stalling and, finally, outright rejection by the Obama administration.

Sure, technically, it was Monday's approval by the Nebraska Public Service Commission that removed the last official hurdle to Keystone XL. But without Trump's approval first, the Nebraskans wouldn't even have made a decision.

A lot can still go wrong. TransCanada Corp. might decide not to go ahead with the 1,800-km extension of their existing Keystone line that would connect Alberta's oilsands with a pipeline hub in Cushing, Oklahoma.

When TransCanada cancelled the Energy East pipeline in October, it did so mostly because of environmental hurdles erected by Justin Trudeau's federal Liberal government. But to the extent that decision was economic, Keystone might prove to be equally uneconomic..

American courts might also side with environmentalists or Nebraska ranchers and issue injunctions against construction. Or protestors might block construction for weeks or months.

So, Keystone is far from a done deal just yet, although it remains the most likely major pipeline to actually get built.

It would be a shame though if Keystone helped Notley get re-elected. At the very best, her attitude towards the project has been lukewarm.

Our premier has held many positions on Keystone, but she has probably been opposed or indifferent more than she has been in favour.

When Notley and the NDP were in opposition before the May 2015 election, they were clearly against the pipeline.

Then during the campaign they sent mixed messages. Candidate Rachel Notley told the Edmonton Sun's editorial board she was in favour of Keystone. Later she told the CBC's Evan Solomon "we're against it."

Shortly after being sworn in as premier in May 2015, her federal NDP brethren came out staunchly against Keystone during the federal election. Notley refused to repudiate their stance.

When Barack Obama announced he was blocking Keystone in November 2015 - the same month the New Dems came out with their carbon tax and climate leadership plan - Notley refused to go to Washington to complain. She made it clear she'd rather Keystone didn't go ahead.

During the last U.S. presidential race, when Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton declared herself against Keystone, Notley said she and Clinton were on the same page.

After Trump was elected in November 2016, Notley refused once again to go to D.C. to lobby for Keystone saying it "was not key."

Now, I suppose, because her "social license" strategy has failed so miserably to get a single Canadian pipeline built, maybe that's why Notley has suddenly become such a big booster of Keystone.

Donald Trump has become Rachel Notley's last, best chance of a second term.


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
usa : United States | namz : North America

IPD 
Column | donald,trump,saved,rachel,political,admittedly

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN
